attributes.title: Delirium inducing medication in people at risk. A systematic update review
attributes.description: Drug induced delirium is a common phenomenon especially in older patients and associated with poor outcomes such as increased rates of hospital-acquired complications, institutionalization and mortality. The evidence of possibly delirium inducing medication is mostly based on case reports and series. Even the English delirium guideline does not provide recommendations on avoiding certain medication (classes) due to a lack of high quality studies (National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, 2010). Nevertheless, reliable data is crucial for clinical prevention measures such as medication reviews. In order to address this problem, we will conduct a systematic literature review to provide a synopsis of current evidence. The latest systematic review on delirium inducing medication retrieved shows that there is uncertainty about most medication classes commonly prescribed and high quality evidence on delirium associations is scarce (Clegg and Young, 2011).

q1.value: Michael Reisinger, Daniela Schoberer, Johanna De Biasi, Eva Reininghaus

q2.value:
The main aim of this study is to evaluate the evidence of associations between medication and delirium with a focus on the elderly population.

We will update a previous systematic review from 2011 (Clegg and Young, 2011) on delirium inducing medication and – if possible – pool data across studies in meta-analyses according to medication classes or substances.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Systematic review and - if possible - meta-analysis

This study will be conducted as a systematic review following the Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines (Moher et al., 2009). I will be based upon the recommendations on data searching, data processing, assessment of risk of bias and the overall quality of evidence as described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Higgins JPT and Green S, 2011).

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value:
As of the date of submission of this pre-registration, one review author partly screened databases and partly extracted data, the other reviewer did not. Database screening and data extraction of included studies have not yet been finished by both of the reviewers. 

No statistical analyses or summary measures / statistics have been conducted so far.

question.value:
Databases will be screened by two independent reviewers for articles meeting the predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria. Predefined data items of included studies will be extracted by one reviewer and checked for correctness by the other independent reviewer. 

Eligibility criteria for inclusion of studies were defined before the systematic database search according to the research question and PICO framework (see eligibility criteria table for details). Interventional and prospective observational studies that report on associations of medication and incidental delirium in adult patients will be included. Retrospective observational studies, case reports, case series and studies that fail to present exploratory statistics or data analyses are considered as providing a low level of evidence and will therefore be excluded. There will be a focus on elderly, over 65 years old patients (via a filter in databases) due to an increased risk of (drug induced) delirium in this population. Nevertheless, all adult study populations (> 18 years old) will be included. English, German and French language journal articles will be included if published after October 2009. This cut-off serves as an update of the previous systematic review (Clegg and Young, 2011).

For details on eligibility criteria, see table "eligibility criteria".
For further explanation about the data collection procedures, see study protocol.

We will extract these predefined data items of included studies:

Study characteristics:
1. study characteristics (authors, publication year, country, study design, clinical setting)
2. study population characteristics (sample size, mean age, inclusion or exclusion of dementia, delirium rate)

Results:
1. medication exposure (medication class or single agent, duration of exposure, dosage)
2. outcome assessment (delirium diagnosis via assessment instruments, diagnostic criteria of DSM / ICD or clinical diagnosis)
3. effect sizes with specification of the type of statistical analysis (e.g. multivariate or univariate analysis).

Primary outcome:
Incidental delirium assessed with diagnostic criteria of DSM or ICD (all versions, respectively), assessment instruments validated against DSM / ICD criteria or clinical diagnosis.

First, results will be summarized in a qualitative analysis.
If applicable, we will perform a quantitative meta-analysis and group comparable studies with regard to associations between medication classes (or single agents) and incidental delirium. The synthesis will be guided by the Cochrane Handbook (Higgins JPT and Green S, 2011). If more than two clinically comparable studies are available, these will be pooled using the random-effects model. This model is more likely to fit the sampling distribution and allows the results to be generalized to a wider array of situations (Borenstein et al., 2009). We will calculate pooled odds ratios/hazard ratios for the dichotomous outcomes with 95% confidence intervals. Statistical heterogeneity will be assessed using χ2 test (with statistically significance set at P < .05) and by calculating the I² statistic (Deeks et al. 2017). We will use the Software Review Manager, Version 5.3 (Review Manager 2014) to compile the meta-analyses and calculate the heterogeneity.

attributes.title: The Effects of Animal-Free Food Technology Awareness on Animal Farming Opposition
attributes.description: There is limited research on the effects that animal-free food technologies (AFFT), such as cultured meat and new plant-based foods that accurately mimic animal products, have on attitudes toward animal farming. This study will provide participants with information about AFFT and test how their animal farming opposition (AFO) differs from those of participants who are provided with information about low-technology plant-based foods or about an unrelated topic. Differences across demographic and psychological variables will be explored.

q2.value:
Hypotheses to be tested through the full model of the planned regression:

Increased awareness of animal-free food technology (AFFT, i.e. cultured meat and high-tech plant-based meat) will have significant positive effects on an overall measure for animal farming opposition (AFO) in the main analysis, when compared to controls.
In the full model, participants with lower preferences for naturalness will have higher attitudes towards farmed animals than participants with higher preferences for naturalness.
In the full model, participants with higher trust in science will have higher attitudes towards farmed animals than participants with lower trust in science.
In the full model, participants with lower speciesism will have higher attitudes towards farmed animals than participants with higher speciesism.
In the full model, participants with higher scores on the "socially desirable response set" variable will have higher attitudes towards farmed animals than participants with lower scores on SDRS.
In the full model, participants who attribute higher mental capacities to animals will have higher attitudes towards farmed animals than participants who attribute lower mental capacities to animals.

Hypotheses to be tested as robustness checks or in exploratory analysis:

Increased awareness of AFFT will decrease participants intention to consume animal products.
Assuming that there is an overall significant positive effect on AFO, the point estimate for the effects on AFA will be more strongly positive for cultured meat than for high-tech plant-based meat.
Assuming that there is an overall significant positive effect on AFO, the point estimate for the effects on AFO will be more strongly positive for AFFT than for low-tech plant-based meat.
Assuming that there is an overall significant positive effect on AFO, the point estimate for the effects on AFO will be more strongly positive for high-tech plant-based meat than for low-tech plant-based meat.
When compared to the mobile data article, the point estimate for the effects on AFO will be more strongly positive for high-tech plant-based meat than for low-tech plant-based meat.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: Participants will not be informed that there are randomly assigned groups in the study. Data collection will be conducted via Positly and there will not be any direct interaction with the study subjects.

question.value:
This survey will be hosted on GuidedTrack, a survey platform that uses easily-customizable code. Code is provided in the appendix of the attached PDF.

We will use Amazon Mechanical Turk workers as our sample pool. We will exclude participants from outside the US and participants who fail a comprehension check question or an attention check question, which has been partly based on Hauser (2015). The participants will be recruited via Positly, which has additional quality checks on participants, such as blocking duplicate IP addresses and blocking suspicious IP addresses. We will run separate versions of the survey for different age and gender groups so that our sample is representative of the US for these two demographic characteristics.

Our calculations suggested that a sample size of around 1500 would be sufficient to detect small effects. This exceeds the sample size that Cohen (1992) suggests would be needed to detect small effects in a multiple regression with 20 independent variables.

Participants will be assigned to one of two AFFT groups or to one of two control groups using simple randomization, with an equal allocation ratio between the four. Comparisons will be made between subjects.

The first intervention group will be shown a short article about the development of cultured meat. The second intervention group will be shown a similar article about the development of high-tech plant-based meats that accurately mimic meat. The first control group will be shown an article about the development of low-tech plant-based foods that do not attempt to accurately mimic meat. The second control group will be shown an unrelated article about the use of mobile data to prevent traffic jams.

The articles were chosen to represent plausible media coverage of animal-free food. The articles were developed from those used in previous studies of the effects of variations in the naming of cultured meat. Word count and reading ease were similar for all four articles.

The appendix contains the full text of the messages. Participants will each see only one message, followed by the AFO outcome questions, demographic questions, and other relevant psychological measures.

The AFO outcome measures have been chosen based on Sentience Institute’s 2017 and 2019 US surveys. The order in which these AFO outcome measures are presented to participants will be randomized.

The demographic questions have been chosen to enable cross-comparability with SI’s (2019) US survey. The questions on distrust in science and food neophobia likewise follow Wilks et al. in adapting questions from Frewer, Scholderer, and Bredahl (2003) and Pliner and Hobden (1992). The questions on preference for naturalness were also from Wilks et al. (2019). Following the recommendations of Hays, Hayashi, and Stewart (1989), a five-item measure of socially desirable response set will be used. The questions on attribution of mental capabilities to animals follow Rothgerber’s (2014) adaptation of the scale used by Bastian et al. (2011). The speciesism scale was developed by Caviola, Everett, and Faber (2018). The order in which participants see the questions on these psychological scales and on demographics will be randomized, as will the order of the sub-questions within each psychological scale. Before the demographic questions, participants will also see questions about familiarity with animal-free foods, based on the question used by Bryant et al. (2019), and a question on participants’ intention to change their consumption of animal products.

question.value:
This survey will be hosted on GuidedTrack, a survey platform that uses easily-customizable code. We will use Amazon Mechanical Turk workers as our sample pool. We will exclude participants from outside the US and participants who fail a comprehension check question or an attention check question, which has been partly based on Hauser (2015). The participants will be recruited via Positly, which has additional quality checks on participants, such as blocking duplicate IP addresses and blocking suspicious IP addresses. We will run separate versions of the survey for different age and gender groups so that our sample is representative of the US for these two demographic characteristics.

In the pilot study, the mean completion time was 10.2 minutes. Based on this, the payment per survey completion was set at $1.30, which equates to a pay rate of $7.65 per hour.

q11.value: The "Desired number of activity completions" on Positly will be set to 1500.

q12.value:
Our calculations suggested that a sample size of around 1500 would be sufficient to detect small effects. 

G* Power was used to compute the required sample size a priori — see Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, and Buchner (2007).

The option “Linear multiple regression: Fixed model, R2 deviation from zero” was selected. The f2 effect size was set to 0.02, which is the conventional cutoff for “small” effect sizes, following Cohen (1988). Alpha (the risk of false positive results) was set to 0.05, the power (the risk of false negative results) was set to 0.80, and the number of predictors was set to 20. This suggested that a total sample size of 1064 would be needed.

However, in our main analysis, we intend to use the methods described by Benjamini and Hochberg (1995) to adjust for multiple hypothesis testing. For the sample size calculation, the alpha should therefore be lower than 0.05, but higher than 0.0025, the value that would be needed for the highly conservative Bonferroni correction, which would suggest a required sample size of 1705.

Our intended sample size of 1500 exceeds the sample size that Cohen (1992) suggests would be needed to detect small effects in a multiple regression with 20 independent variables; Cohen suggests that with a significance criterion of .05 and power at .80, a sample size of 757 would be needed to detect small differences in a multiple regression with 8 independent variables. For each additional independent variable included in the regression beyond 8 independent variables, it seems that the increase in required sample size will be 31 or fewer; this study will use 20 independent variables, suggesting that a total sample size of around 1100 would be sufficient.

question.value:
Only one variable with be manipulated; the article that participants are asked to read before completing the survey questions.

The first intervention group will be shown a short article about the development of cultured meat. The second intervention group will be shown a similar article about the development of high-tech plant-based meats that accurately mimic meat. The first control group will be shown an article about the development of low-tech plant-based foods that do not attempt to accurately mimic meat. The second control group will be shown an unrelated article about the use of mobile data to prevent traffic jams.

The articles were chosen to represent plausible media coverage of animal-free food. The articles were developed from those used in previous studies of the effects of variations in the naming of cultured meat. Word count and reading ease were similar for all four articles.

The main aim of this study is to assess whether and to what extent Animal Farming Opposition (AFO) is affected by the provision of information about AFFT.

In this study, AFO will be measured through five questions from Sentience Institute’s 2017 and 2019 US surveys, selected based on exploratory factor analysis. These questions ask about people’s willingness to support bans on animal farming, factory farming, or slaughterhouses, their willingness to join a demonstration against factory farming, and their discomfort with the way animals are used in the food industry.

The demographic questions have been chosen to enable cross-comparability with SI’s (2019) US survey. The questions on distrust in science and food neophobia likewise follow Wilks et al. in adapting questions from Frewer, Scholderer, and Bredahl (2003) and Pliner and Hobden (1992). The questions on preference for naturalness were also from Wilks et al. (2019). Following the recommendations of Hays, Hayashi, and Stewart (1989), a five-item measure of socially desirable response set will be used. The questions on attribution of mental capabilities to animals follow Rothgerber’s (2014) adaptation of the scale used by Bastian et al. (2011). The speciesism scale was developed by Caviola, Everett, and Faber (2018). The order in which participants see the questions on these psychological scales and on demographics will be randomized, as will the order of the sub-questions within each psychological scale. Before the demographic questions, participants will also see questions about familiarity with animal-free foods, based on the question used by Bryant et al. (2019), and a question on participants’ intention to change their consumption of animal products.

For the AFO outcome measures, the mean of question responses will be used as the scale. 

Linear regression will assess whether and to what extent the overall AFO score is affected by 1) whether the participant was shown information about AFFT (either cultured meat or meat-like plant-based meat) or one of the two control groups (low-tech plant-based meat or the use of mobile data to prevent traffic jams), 2) participant demographic variables, using the most common characteristic as the comparison group for categorical variables with three or more categories, and 3) other relevant psychological measures, where the mean of question responses will be used as the scale, except for in the five-item measure of socially desirable response set, which will be analyzed as a score between 0 and 5.

The statistical analysis will be done with R with code available in the appendix of the attached PDF.

For the AFO outcome measures, the mean of question responses will be used as the scale.

Linear regression will be carried out with the dependent variable being the overall AFO “score.” The regression will assess whether and to what extent the overall AFO score is affected by 1) whether the participant was shown information about AFFT or one of the two control groups, 2) participant demographic variables, and 3) other relevant psychological measures, where the mean of question responses will be used as the scale, except for in the five-item measure of socially desirable response set, which will be analyzed as a score between 0 and 5.

q18.value: The regression analysis will use a binary categorical variable for whether the participant was shown information about AFFT (either cultured meat or meat-like plant-based meat) or one of the two control groups (low-tech plant-based meat or the use of mobile data to prevent traffic jams). The participant demographic variables will be analyzed using the most common characteristic as the comparison group for categorical variables with three or more categories.

q19.value:
A controlled false discovery rate (FDR) of 0.1 will be used, meaning we are 90% sure any given significant result reflects an actual difference in animal attitudes, for the 20 tests in the confirmatory analysis. The methods described in Benjamini and Hochberg (1995) will be used to control the FDR.

This may be adjusted if fewer than 5 tests yield significant results with 90% FDR.

q20.value: We will exclude participants from outside the US and participants who fail a comprehension check question or an attention check question, which has been partly based on Hauser (2015). The participants will be recruited via Positly, which has additional quality checks on participants, such as blocking duplicate IP addresses and blocking suspicious IP addresses.

q21.value: Non-responses and participants who fail the attention or quality checks will be excluded, though multiple imputation may be used for missing data if assumptions are met and we may take other measures if the survey software creates a large number of missing data points.

q22.value:
As exploratory analysis, variations of the regression described above will be carried out with fewer predictors.  We plan to conduct analysis of: 1) a model testing only the effect of varying the treatment group, 2) a model that also incorporates demographic variables, 3) the full model minus the psychological measures that seem intuitively most similar to the AFO outcome measure — speciesism and the attribution of mental capabilities to animals, and 4) the full model plus a variable that accounts for familiarity with AFFT.

Additional variations will be carried out that compare more directly between different combinations of treatment groups.  We plan to conduct analysis of: 1) both AFFT types compared to the use of mobile data article, with low-tech plant-based meat excluded entirely 2) both AFFT types compared to low-tech plant-based meat, 3) cultured meat compared to high-tech plant-based meat, 4) high-tech plant-based meat compared to low-tech plant-based meat, and 5) low-tech plant-based meat compared to the use of mobile data article.

Additional regressions will be carried out that check whether participants’ speciesism, attribution of mental capacities to animals, or intention to change their consumption of animal products are affected by AFFT awareness. 

Regressions may also be carried out for individual outcome measurements and interaction effects (e.g. food neophobia and treatment group). Additional random effects modeling may be run as robustness checks.

The questions on distrust in science and food neophobia likewise follow Wilks et al. in adapting questions from Frewer, Scholderer, and Bredahl (2003) and Pliner and Hobden (1992). The questions on preference for naturalness were also from Wilks et al. (2019). Following the recommendations of Hays, Hayashi, and Stewart (1989), a five-item measure of socially desirable response set will be used. The questions on attribution of mental capabilities to animals follow Rothgerber’s (2014) adaptation of the scale used by Bastian et al. (2011). The speciesism scale was developed by Caviola, Everett, and Faber (2018). The order in which participants see the questions on these psychological scales and on demographics will be randomized, as will the order of the sub-questions within each psychological scale. Before the demographic questions, participants will also see questions about familiarity with animal-free foods, based on the question used by Bryant et al. (2019), and a question on participants’ intention to change their consumption of animal products.

q6.uploader.file_name: Pre-registration The Effects of Animal-Free Food Technology Awareness on Animal Farming Opposition.pdf

registration_responses.q10.question:
This survey will be hosted on GuidedTrack, a survey platform that uses easily-customizable code. We will use Amazon Mechanical Turk workers as our sample pool. We will exclude participants from outside the US and participants who fail a comprehension check question or an attention check question, which has been partly based on Hauser (2015). The participants will be recruited via Positly, which has additional quality checks on participants, such as blocking duplicate IP addresses and blocking suspicious IP addresses. We will run separate versions of the survey for different age and gender groups so that our sample is representative of the US for these two demographic characteristics.

In the pilot study, the mean completion time was 10.2 minutes. Based on this, the payment per survey completion was set at $1.30, which equates to a pay rate of $7.65 per hour.
registration_responses.q14.question:
Only one variable with be manipulated; the article that participants are asked to read before completing the survey questions.

The first intervention group will be shown a short article about the development of cultured meat. The second intervention group will be shown a similar article about the development of high-tech plant-based meats that accurately mimic meat. The first control group will be shown an article about the development of low-tech plant-based foods that do not attempt to accurately mimic meat. The second control group will be shown an unrelated article about the use of mobile data to prevent traffic jams.

The articles were chosen to represent plausible media coverage of animal-free food. The articles were developed from those used in previous studies of the effects of variations in the naming of cultured meat. Word count and reading ease were similar for all four articles.
registration_responses.q15.question:
The main aim of this study is to assess whether and to what extent Animal Farming Opposition (AFO) is affected by the provision of information about AFFT.

In this study, AFO will be measured through five questions from Sentience Institute’s 2017 and 2019 US surveys, selected based on exploratory factor analysis. These questions ask about people’s willingness to support bans on animal farming, factory farming, or slaughterhouses, their willingness to join a demonstration against factory farming, and their discomfort with the way animals are used in the food industry.

The demographic questions have been chosen to enable cross-comparability with SI’s (2019) US survey. The questions on distrust in science and food neophobia likewise follow Wilks et al. in adapting questions from Frewer, Scholderer, and Bredahl (2003) and Pliner and Hobden (1992). The questions on preference for naturalness were also from Wilks et al. (2019). Following the recommendations of Hays, Hayashi, and Stewart (1989), a five-item measure of socially desirable response set will be used. The questions on attribution of mental capabilities to animals follow Rothgerber’s (2014) adaptation of the scale used by Bastian et al. (2011). The speciesism scale was developed by Caviola, Everett, and Faber (2018). The order in which participants see the questions on these psychological scales and on demographics will be randomized, as will the order of the sub-questions within each psychological scale. Before the demographic questions, participants will also see questions about familiarity with animal-free foods, based on the question used by Bryant et al. (2019), and a question on participants’ intention to change their consumption of animal products.
registration_responses.q16.question:
For the AFO outcome measures, the mean of question responses will be used as the scale. 

Linear regression will assess whether and to what extent the overall AFO score is affected by 1) whether the participant was shown information about AFFT (either cultured meat or meat-like plant-based meat) or one of the two control groups (low-tech plant-based meat or the use of mobile data to prevent traffic jams), 2) participant demographic variables, using the most common characteristic as the comparison group for categorical variables with three or more categories, and 3) other relevant psychological measures, where the mean of question responses will be used as the scale, except for in the five-item measure of socially desirable response set, which will be analyzed as a score between 0 and 5.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The statistical analysis will be done with R with code available in the appendix of the attached PDF.

For the AFO outcome measures, the mean of question responses will be used as the scale.

Linear regression will be carried out with the dependent variable being the overall AFO “score.” The regression will assess whether and to what extent the overall AFO score is affected by 1) whether the participant was shown information about AFFT or one of the two control groups, 2) participant demographic variables, and 3) other relevant psychological measures, where the mean of question responses will be used as the scale, except for in the five-item measure of socially desirable response set, which will be analyzed as a score between 0 and 5.

attributes.title: Influence of item desirability on pairwise item correlation
attributes.description: Predicting correlations between items from the product of their centered social desirability ratings. This pre-registration contains Samples 5 and 6.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

sample.value:
All data has already been collected, as part of studies unrelated to the present research question. The self-ratings (n = 849) and the informant-reports (n = 515) come from different convenience samples, as reported in the respective original studies (Zimmermann et al., 2015; Zimmermann et al., in press).   
The social desirability of the 80 items used in Sample 5 was rated 30 participants, specifically for the present analyses. Data collection took place between March 22 and March 26 of 2020. The social desirability of the 60 items used in Sample 6 was rated by 24 participants, as part of the Study by Leising et al. (2018). Previous studies have shown that such sample sizes are sufficient to obtain average ratings of item desirabilty that are almost perfectly reliable.

analyses.value:
The procedure is very similar to the one used before. We calculate Pearson's r between all (Fisher’s Z-transformed) pairwise inter-item-correlations and the products of the respective items’ social desirability ratings. The latter will be rescaled such that the middle of the response scale (e.g., 4 in a scale ranging from 1 to 7) becomes zero, the lower end (e.g., 1) becomes -1 and the upper end (e.g., 7) becomes 1. This is done to enable direct comparisons between studies using different response formats.  
One effect size will be obtained for the Sample 5 and one for Sample 6. 95%-confidence intervals (one for each of the two effect sizes) will be determined using Bootstrapping.

outliers.value: Participants showing evidence of careless processing were already excluded in the original studies (see Zimmermann et al., 2015; Zimmermann et al., in the press, for details). We do not exclude any further data points.

dependent.value:
In Sample 5 (self-report), the participants judged themselves on 80 items assessing their “level of personality functioning” (1 = totally false, not at all true, 2 = slightly true, 3 = mainly true, 4 = very true; Morey, 2017). These items were independently rated for social desirability by a group of 30 raters (1 = very negative, 4 = neutral, 7 = very positive), specifically to enable the present analyses. 
In Sample 6, perceivers rated their respective targets on the 60 individual statements from the Level of Personality Functioning Scale (0 = not at all, 3 = very true), which is part of the Alternative Model for Personality Disorders (AMPD) in DSM-5 (American Psychiatric Association, 2013). These items were independently rated for social desirability by a group of 24 raters (0 = Not at all, 1 = a little, 2 = moderately, 3 = quite, 4 = very), as part of the study bei Leising et al. (2018).

conditions.value: There were no experimental conditions in Sample 5. In Sample 6, participants were randomly assigned to one of two different instructions: In one third of the cases, they were asked to select a person they knew well “who is psychologically healthy”. In the remaining two thirds of the cases, participants were asked to select a person they knew well “who has mental health or interpersonal problems.” This is likely to increase the variance of the participants responses to the items, but will be ignored in the present context.

hypothesis.value: The basic research question is the same as in the four related pre-registrations preceding this one (): We expect that the product of two items’ centered social desirability ratings predicts the correlation between the two items. Given the findings obtained in the four previous rounds of analyses, we again expect the effect size to be larger (around r = .60) for informant-reports than for self-reports (around r = .40).

study_type_other.value:
Yes, all of the data has been collected already. Here, we pre-register analyses using two additional datasets. Both contain judgments of the “level of personality functioning” of targets, but the first dataset (Sample 5) contains self-reports whereas the second dataset (Sample 6) contains informant-reports. The items used in the two sample are similar, but not identical, in number and content.  
The self-reports in Sample 5 come from a recently published study by Zimmermann et al. (in press), and the ratings of the items’ social desirability were collected specifically for the present analyses, between March 22 and March 26 of 2020. The informant-reports in Sample 6 come from the study by Zimmermann et al. (2015), and the ratings of the items’ social desirability are the ones used in Leising, Scherbaum, Packmohr & Zimmermann (2018).

attributes.title: Sleep during the coronavirus pandemic
attributes.description:
Sleep quality is affected by several factors such as routine (Zisberg et al. 2010), natural light exposure (Wams et al. 2017), use of media devices (Carter et al. 2016), health status (Ohida et al. 2001), anxiety and depression (Alvaro et al. 2013), and post-traumatic stress disorder (Spoormaker and Montgomery 2008).

Covid-19 emerged at the end of 2019 in Wuhan, China - and spread globally in the first few months of 2020 - leading to 'lockdown' in different areas around the world. This situation has led to seismic changes in day-to-day life, with people having been told to 'socially distance', 'socially isolate', work from home and stay indoors. This stressful situation and this dramatic change in day-to-day life in society is likely accompanied by multiple changes that impact upon sleep - including changes to working arrangements, routine, exercise, diet, stress levels, anxiety and depression, and health as well as time spent using electronic devices and in isolation. 

While many of these factors are typically associated with reduced sleep quality - there are other changes that could also result in increased opportunity for sleep - including a reduction in commuting time, and less time spent on other activities (outdoor activities and social activities) - increasing the time available to sleep. 

We started collecting cross-sectional data on sleep (in the context of a wider study focusing more generally on touch) in January and will continue collecting until the end of March. Given our large sample size, we plan to study responses received at different time points in order to examine changes in sleep over this unusual period in history.  

This study investigates sleep quality during the first 3 months of the COVID-19 outbreak. Cross sectional data regarding sleep quality and quantity and diurnal preference was collected among the population during the first 3 months of 2020. 

We hypothesized that sleep quality will be worst as the pandemic progresses, whereas sleep quantity will remain stable or increase. We do not predict changes in diurnal preference.

q1.value: Juan J Madrid-Valero, Alice Gregory, Michael J. Banissy, Natalie Bowling

q2.value:
Sleep quality will decrease over time (ie those completing the questionnaire later will report poorer sleep quality)

Sleep quantity will remain stable or increase over time (ie those completing the questionnaire later will not report shorter sleep as compared to those completing the questionnaire earlier, and may report longer sleep duration)

Diurnal preference will not show substantial changes across the study

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales. See Variables section for further detail. We will extract the relevant scales outlined in the Variables section from this dataset to exploring specific questions linked to this project.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: Data collection for this project has already begun but is not yet completed. It is currently held online on the Qualtrics survey platform. The data will be accessed and analysed after data collection is completed on 30/03/2020.

question.value: Participants have been recruited through broadcasts on the BBC and other media. There is no monetary incentive to take part. Participants must be aged over 18 years old and have internet access on a computer, smart phone or tablet to participate.

q11.value: Our target sample size is restricted by date (30/03/2020) as the project is a collaboration with the BBC/Wellcome Collection and the stopping date is set by these partners. Based on similar prior projects run by BBC/Wellcome Collection we envisage a minimum sample of ~20,000 participants from the UK.

q12.value: G*Power  statistical software will be used to conduct a power analysis. Our goal is to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. This test will be performed in order to check the statistical power for country stratification (i.e. the minimum sample required per country should we be able to conduct country specific analyses).

q13.value: Our stopping criteria are restricted by date (30/03/2020) as the project is a collaboration with the BBC/Wellcome Collection and the stopping date is set by these partners.

question.value:
Sleep Questions: 

A) How would you rate your sleep quality for the majority of nights during the past month?
•  Very good
•  Fairly Good
•  Fairly Bad
•  Very Bad

B) During the majority of the days and nights in the past month how many hours of actual sleep did you get at night? This may be different to the number of hours you spent in bed.
•	> 9 hours
•	8-9 hours
•	7-8 hours
•	6-7 hours
•	5-6 hours
•	< 5 hours

C) Thinking about a typical night in the last month... How long does it take you to fall asleep?
•	0-15 minutes
•	16-30 minutes
•	31- 45 minutes
•	46-60 minutes
•	61 minutes or more

D) If you then wake up during the night, how long are you awake in total (add up all the time when you are awake)?
•	0-15 minutes
•	16-30 minutes
•	31-45 minutes
•	46-60 minutes
•	61 minutes or more

E) How many times did you wake up between the time you first fell asleep and your final awakening?
•	0
•	1
•	2
•	3
•	4 or more

F) One hears about "morning" and "evening" types of people. Which one of these do you consider yourself to be?
•	Definitely a morning type
•	Rather more a morning type than an evening type
•	Rather more an evening type than a morning type
•	Definitely an evening type

Demographic questions:
Age 
Employment status
Main field of work
Gender
Country of residence
(If UK) Region of the UK
(If UK) Ethnicity
Disability, long-term condition or impairment
Survey date of completion

General comment: We shall focus our analyses on participants from the UK (as COVID-19 developed at different countries at different times) that indicate on the survey that “I do not have any disability, long-term condition or impairment”.

Please note that if we have the power, we will also look at our questions separately in participants from different countries (focusing on the countries with the most responses and hence power to address our questions).

Group level differences and data visualisation:
For data focusing on UK participants, we shall present the frequencies for the following variables across the entire UK sample:

•	How would you rate your sleep quality for the majority of nights during the past month? (Sleep quality)
•	During the majority of the days and nights in the past month how many hours of actual sleep did you get at night? This may be different to the number of hours you spent in bed. (Sleep quantity)
•	Thinking about a typical night in the last month...How long does it take you to fall asleep? (Sleep quality)
•	If you then wake up during the night, how long are you awake in total (add up all the time when you are awake)? (Sleep quality)
•	How many times did you wake up between the time you first fell asleep and your final awakening? (Sleep quality)
•	One hears about "morning" and "evening" types of people. Which one of these do you consider yourself to be? (Diurnal preference)

We will divide the sample and present in at least one of three ways: 1) by week of testing, 2) responses received in January, those received in February and those received in March, and 3) responses before ten cases of Covid-19 and after ten cases of Covid-19 in a given region of interest (e.g. in England – before 24/02/20 versus after 24/02/20 based on cases reported by Public Health England). The descriptive statistics may also consider differences by age, sex, and region of the UK. 

To compare differences between groups on these variables we will run appropriate parametric (e.g. t-test for two groups; ANOVA for multiple groups/levels) or non-parametric comparisons (e.g. chi-square for frequency data; permutation tests) – please also see data transformation section. Alpha levels will be constrained as per our inference criteria section. 

We predict the following (note, although in some cases we have directional predictions we will use two-tailed tests throughout): 
1.	Sleep quality will decrease over time (i.e.  those completing the questionnaire later will report poorer sleep quality)
2.	Sleep quantity will remain stable or increase over time (i.e. those completing the questionnaire later will not report shorter sleep as compared to those completing the questionnaire earlier, and may report longer sleep duration)
3.	Diurnal preference will not show substantial changes across the study.

Correlation and Regression analyses:
In addition to group level comparisons we will also run correlational and regression analyses. 

Our main predictor variable of interest will be day/week of completion of the questionnaire (hereafter called Time of Completion). Note, we will define if we use day or week based on the final sample size that will be clear once the data has been accessed. We define day as our preferred option, but due to opportunity sampling nature of the project we may have to restrict analysis to week of completion. We will examine if Time of Completion predicts responses to the individual sleep item variables – that is to say we will run separate regressions for each sleep/diurnal preference variable of interest. We shall run additional regression analyses where we control for sex, age, ethnicity in our analyses.

q18.value:
Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests). For moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar will be applied. For extreme deviations from normality, we will use equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 

For group comparisons we will remove any outliers that are three standard deviations away from the group average. We will also compare data with and without group outliers as a sensitivity analysis.

To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant.

Depending on the data distribution, sleep variables could be dichotomised (e.g. some categories are poorly endorsed).

q19.value: We will use the following alpha levels: <.005 for all correlations, <.01 given sample size for all regressions, <.05 for group level comparisons. Bonferroni correction will be applied to follow up on any group level comparisons where relevant.

q21.value: Participants who have completed at least 80% of items from a given scale or subscale will be included in analysis. If analysis focuses on a single item/question from the survey we will include all participants who complete the question.

q22.value:
We may also attempt to adopt a generalised linear mixed model (GLMM) approach in order to quantify how Covid-19 is linked to changes in attitudes towards touch. Given the unprecedented nature of Covid-19 there is also a high likelihood that additional analyses of interest will arise within our research team or the wider community. For instance, if we have appropriate sample sizes we may examine sleep among specific professional groups. This will also be influenced by the geographical distribution of participants in the current study and when in time participants completed our survey. 

We may also conduct additional exploratory analyses using cluster analysis approaches (e.g. k-means, finite mixture models, finite mixture models of regression models) to identify sub-groups of participants based on their self-reported sleep. We will then seek to compare any sub-groups on variables of interest. Note, that in this context we may in future work also seek to explore additional items from the full Touch Test survey that are not mentioned as part of our planned analyses above. The purpose of this will be to take advantage of a large-scale data set with a view to providing a detailed understanding of factors that interact with differences in sleep during Covid-19 and to promote future research avenues. 

In all scientific communications, any exploratory or additional analyses will be clearly labelled as such. Further, any deviations from these analyses will be noted. Where possible, we will pre-register future re-analyses of these data, for example as part of student projects or similar.

F) One hears about "morning" and "evening" types of people. Which one of these do you consider yourself to be?
•	Definitely a morning type
•	Rather more a morning type than an evening type
•	Rather more an evening type than a morning type
•	Definitely an evening type

Demographic questions:
Age 
Employment status
Main field of work
Gender
Country of residence
(If UK) Region of the UK
(If UK) Ethnicity
Disability, long-term condition or impairment
Survey date of completion
registration_responses.q17.question:
General comment: We shall focus our analyses on participants from the UK (as COVID-19 developed at different countries at different times) that indicate on the survey that “I do not have any disability, long-term condition or impairment”.

Please note that if we have the power, we will also look at our questions separately in participants from different countries (focusing on the countries with the most responses and hence power to address our questions).

Group level differences and data visualisation:
For data focusing on UK participants, we shall present the frequencies for the following variables across the entire UK sample:

•	How would you rate your sleep quality for the majority of nights during the past month? (Sleep quality)
•	During the majority of the days and nights in the past month how many hours of actual sleep did you get at night? This may be different to the number of hours you spent in bed. (Sleep quantity)
•	Thinking about a typical night in the last month...How long does it take you to fall asleep? (Sleep quality)
•	If you then wake up during the night, how long are you awake in total (add up all the time when you are awake)? (Sleep quality)
•	How many times did you wake up between the time you first fell asleep and your final awakening? (Sleep quality)
•	One hears about "morning" and "evening" types of people. Which one of these do you consider yourself to be? (Diurnal preference)

We will divide the sample and present in at least one of three ways: 1) by week of testing, 2) responses received in January, those received in February and those received in March, and 3) responses before ten cases of Covid-19 and after ten cases of Covid-19 in a given region of interest (e.g. in England – before 24/02/20 versus after 24/02/20 based on cases reported by Public Health England). The descriptive statistics may also consider differences by age, sex, and region of the UK. 

To compare differences between groups on these variables we will run appropriate parametric (e.g. t-test for two groups; ANOVA for multiple groups/levels) or non-parametric comparisons (e.g. chi-square for frequency data; permutation tests) – please also see data transformation section. Alpha levels will be constrained as per our inference criteria section. 

We predict the following (note, although in some cases we have directional predictions we will use two-tailed tests throughout): 
1.	Sleep quality will decrease over time (i.e.  those completing the questionnaire later will report poorer sleep quality)
2.	Sleep quantity will remain stable or increase over time (i.e. those completing the questionnaire later will not report shorter sleep as compared to those completing the questionnaire earlier, and may report longer sleep duration)
3.	Diurnal preference will not show substantial changes across the study.

Correlation and Regression analyses:
In addition to group level comparisons we will also run correlational and regression analyses. 

Our main predictor variable of interest will be day/week of completion of the questionnaire (hereafter called Time of Completion). Note, we will define if we use day or week based on the final sample size that will be clear once the data has been accessed. We define day as our preferred option, but due to opportunity sampling nature of the project we may have to restrict analysis to week of completion. We will examine if Time of Completion predicts responses to the individual sleep item variables – that is to say we will run separate regressions for each sleep/diurnal preference variable of interest. We shall run additional regression analyses where we control for sex, age, ethnicity in our analyses.

attributes.title: The effect of fixture congestion on injury in professional male soccer: a systematic review with meta-analysis
attributes.description: A systematic review and meta-analysis of literature related to injuries in soccer that occur during periods of fixture congestion.

q1.value: Liam David Harper, Richard Page, Ross Julian

q2.value: As this is a systematic review and meta-analysis we do not have a specific hypothesis.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic review and meta-analysis following PRISMA guidelines.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Search Terms –
“football” and “soccer” associated with:
“Injury”
“fixture congestion” “congestion” “congested” “match congestion” (also check reference lists and papers known to the authors)

Inclusion/Exclusion Criteria
Inclusion: 1) relevant data concerning periods of fixture congestion on injuries in soccer; 2) minimum of two matches ≤ 96 hours; 3) included professional male soccer players; 4) articles published in English; 5) Injury that results in unavailability for training and/or match-play

Exclusion: 1) included females or non-professional players; 2) data only assessed the impact of congestion on performance and technical and tactical responses; 3) included matches that required extra-time; 4) Grey literature (e.g. theses, dissertations, and conference abstracts); 5) review articles

Databases - PubMed, SPORTDiscus, MEDLINE, Web of Science, Scopus; searched independently by two authors with any ambiguity reviewed by a third author
The articles that fit the inclusion criteria will be checked for variables that will be analysed (e.g., injury risk)

As this is a systematic review/meta-analysis a specific statistical model will not necessarily be used. PRISMA guidelines will be followed for the systematic searching of literature. For the meta-analysis a package in R will be used, namely, 'metafor'.  Weighted estimation of standardised mean differences (SMD) will be calculated, as well as statistical heterogeneity. Hedges’ G values will be plotted against standard errors to visually inspect funnel plot asymmetry. This will be further assessed using Egger’s regression test (if no. of articles above 10) and Duval and Tweedie’s Trim and Fill method.

Quality assessment of the included articles will be undertaken using https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health-topics/study-quality-assessment-tools

attributes.title: The Effect of Activating Public Service Motivation and Prosocial Motivation on Ethical Reporting against Colleagues and Patients

q1.value: The Effect of Activating Public Service Motivation and Prosocial Motivation on Ethical Reporting against Colleagues and Patients

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The rational of this paper is twofold. First, it relates to the conceptual confusion of the concept of public service motivation (Bozeman and Sue 2016; Schott, Neumann, Beartschi & Ritz 2019). In particular, scholars criticize that after 30 years of research there still is a lack of clarity as to how PSM overlaps with and differs from related concepts, such as prosocial motivation and altruism. We aim to show that public service motivation and prosocial motivation are empirically distinct concepts, by studying their relationship with different outcomes, while controlling for the respective other type of motivation. Second, evidence on the causal effects of public service motivation in general and on ethical behavior in particular remain scare (Meyer-Sahling, Mikkelsen , Schuster 2018). By drawing on a novel experimental survey design (randomizing the order of public service motivation and ethical outcome questions) we aim to contribute to this lack in knowledge. Sources Bozeman, B., & Su, X. (2015). Public service motivation concepts and theory: A critique. Public Administration Review, 75(5), 700-710. Schott, C., Neumann, O., Baertschi, M., & Ritz, A. (2019). Public Service Motivation, Prosocial Motivation and Altruism: Towards Disentanglement and Conceptual Clarity. International Journal of Public Administration, 1-12. Meyer-Sahling, J. H., Mikkelsen, K. S., & Schuster, C. (2018). The Causal Effect of Public Service Motivation on Ethical Behavior in the Public Sector: Evidence from a Large-Scale Survey Experiment. Journal of Public Administration Research and Theory, 29(3), 445-459.

q16.value: On basis of the literature, we expect the following about PSM and willingness to report ethical problems: H1a. There is a positive relationship between PSM and the willingness to report ethical problems. H1b. For employees with PSM activation, the effect of PSM levels on reporting ethical problems is stronger. Since the literature on PM and willingness is divided, we propose contrasting hypotheses: H2a-1. There is a positive relationship between PM and the willingness to report ethical problems. H2a-2. There is a negative relationship between PM and the willingness to report ethical problems. H2b. For employees with PM activation, the effect of PM levels on reporting ethical problems is stronger. We also expect differences between PSM and PM. Please mind, if H2a-2 is accepted, H3 must be true too. However, if H2a-1 is true, H3 could, but does not have to, be true. H3. Employee with higher PSM levels are more willing to report ethical problems than employees with higher PM levels. The last hypothesis is additional and may not be included in the academic publication. Yet, we expect the following to be true regarding the difference between reporting of colleagues and patients: H4. Employees are more willing to report ethical problems regarding colleagues compared to patients.

q17.value: Hypotheses will be tested through regression analyses in SPSS. We will also report a full correlation table and factor analyses.

attributes.title: DynaCORE-C: The DynaMORE cross-sectional survey study on psychological resilience to the mental health consequences of the Corona crisis
attributes.description:
The current Corona pandemic is not only a threat to physical health. First data from China and the United Kingdom indicate that symptoms of anxiety and depression and perceptions of stress rise significantly as a consequence of the pandemic. There are also anecdotal reports in the general media of increased domestic violence, divorce and suicide rates. Hence, the Corona crisis is also a mental health crisis. Threats to public mental health are likely to further increase with the spread of the virus across the world and the potentially severe economic, societal and political side effects of the pandemic. In this situation, there is urgent need for knowledge about factors that can protect mental health in this world-wide crisis and that can be harnessed in the service of public mental health promotion. DynaCORE-C attempts to identify these protective factors (resilience factors) with the help of an internet-based cross-sectional questionnaire survey for adults available in multiple languages. 

Our dependent variable is resilience. In keeping with current conceptualizations of this construct (Bonanno et al., 2015; Kalisch et al., 2017), we define resilience as an outcome of good mental health despite exposure to adversity (outcome-based resilience) and measure it by relating mental health outcomes to experienced stressors (Kalisch et al., 2015), which we extensively sample. That is, we do not rely on resilience questionnaires to obtain our dependent variable. In defining our hypotheses about independent variables (resilience factors), we focus on modifiable factors that can be targeted by prevention measures. Specifically, we hypothesize that social support, an increase in social support during the Corona crisis, optimism, general self-efficacy, good stress recovery, positive appraisal style (primary hypothesis), positive appraisal specifically of the Corona crisis, and behavioral coping are positively associated with resilience (outcome), while neuroticism is negatively associated with resilience. We also hypothesize that the expected positive effect of social support on resilience is positively mediated by its effect on positive appraisal style, and that the expected positive effect of positive appraisal style on resilience is positively mediated by its effect on stress recovery. Open questions in the survey allow for detecting potential non-hypothesized resilience factors. 

Analyses will be conducted in the whole sample. Subgroup analyses will be conducted for socio-demographic and health characteristics such as gender, country of residence, occupation, or belonging to a risk group. Further, different phases of the crisis (during official general movement or contact restrictions and after the loosening of these restrictions) will be considered. This will allow us to gain insights into which resilience factors are most effective in which groups and at what times of the crisis and how preventive interventions can be optimally targeted.

summary.value: The attached preregistration document "DynaCORE-C_preregistration_nr1_final_rk20200401.pdf" contains the sections: Title, Authors, Description, Introduction and derivation of hypotheses and outcome measures, Design Plan, Sampling Plan, Analysis Plan, References. The project is on-going. In particular, this preregistration nr. 1 determines a first interim analysis that will be used for a first data report and for the definition of the further analysis plan. The further analysis plan will also be preregistered.
